articles.headline: For Non-Tech Companies, if You Can’t Build It, Buy a Start-Up
articles.snippet: With more than $125 billion in acquisitions last year, more non-tech companies than ever are forgoing building technology in-house and acquiring start-ups.
articles.abstract: With more than $125 billion in acquisitions last year, more non-tech companies than ever are forgoing building technology in-house and acquiring start-ups.
articles.lead_paragraph: For years, mergers and acquisitions in technology were fairly straightforward: Every investment bank kept a list of a dozen or so companies like Google and IBM that had a track record of acquisitions and cash to deploy. When the time and price were right, bankers would seek to match the tech giants with a start-up, and a deal would be hatched.

articles.headline: Inside Trump Defense Secretary Pick’s Efforts to Halt Torture
articles.snippet: James N. Mattis, a retired general, has long been an outspoken critic of torture. His handling of the death of a prisoner that occurred on his watch during the Iraq war reflects his views.
articles.abstract: James N. Mattis, a retired general, has long been an outspoken critic of torture. His handling of the death of a prisoner that occurred on his watch during the Iraq war reflects his views.
articles.lead_paragraph: The body of the Iraqi prisoner was found naked and badly bruised in 2003, outside a detention center in southern Iraq run by United States Marines. The 52-year-old man had been beaten, deprived of sleep, forced to stand for long periods and interrogated by Marines about his alleged role in a fatal ambush of American forces.
articles.byline: By Sheri Fink and Helene Cooper

articles.headline: After Obama, Some Health Reforms May Prove Lasting
articles.snippet: A transformation of the delivery of health care may be an enduring legacy for the president, even as Republicans plan to repeal the Affordable Care Act.
articles.abstract: A transformation of the delivery of health care may be an enduring legacy for the president, even as Republicans plan to repeal the Affordable Care Act.
articles.lead_paragraph: FISHERS, Ind. — Fragments of bone and cartilage arced across the operating room as Dr. R. Michael Meneghini drilled into the knee of his first patient at a hospital here at dawn. Within an hour, the 66-year-old woman had a replacement joint made of titanium and cobalt chrome, and she was sent home the next day.
articles.byline: By Abby Goodnough and Robert Pear

articles.headline: With No Warning, House Republicans Vote to Gut Independent Ethics Office
articles.snippet: The move by emboldened Republicans on the eve of a new Congress would strip power and independence from an investigative body and give lawmakers control over ethics inquiries.
articles.abstract: The move by emboldened Republicans on the eve of a new Congress would strip power and independence from an investigative body and give lawmakers control over ethics inquiries.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — House Republicans, overriding their top leaders, voted on Monday to significantly curtail the power of an independent ethics office set up in 2008 in the aftermath of corruption scandals that sent three members of Congress to jail.

articles.headline: With Trump, an Economic Feast With Surprises on the Menu
articles.snippet: Welcome to the annual DealBook closing dinner at the Trump International Hotel, time to toast and roast the year’s deal makers and to look ahead.
articles.abstract: Welcome to the annual DealBook closing dinner at the Trump International Hotel, time to toast and roast the year’s deal makers and to look ahead.
articles.lead_paragraph: Ladies and gentlemen, please, please take your seats. It is time again for our annual DealBook closing dinner, where we look back at the year that was to toast and roast the year’s deal makers and look ahead to what may come next.

articles.headline: India’s Call-Center Talents Put to a Criminal Use: Swindling Americans
articles.snippet: The availability of computer-savvy, young, English-speaking job seekers and efficient technology have contributed to the growth in cyberfraud against Americans.
articles.abstract: The availability of computer-savvy, young, English-speaking job seekers and efficient technology have contributed to the growth in cyberfraud against Americans.
articles.lead_paragraph: THANE, India — Betsy Broder, who tracks international fraud at the Federal Trade Commission, was in her office in Washington last summer when she got a call from two Indian teenagers.

articles.headline: House Republicans, Under Fire, Back Down on Gutting Ethics Office
articles.snippet: Lawmakers, facing a storm of bipartisan criticism, including from President-elect Donald J. Trump, reversed their steps against the Office of Congressional Ethics.
articles.abstract: Lawmakers, facing a storm of bipartisan criticism, including from President-elect Donald J. Trump, reversed their steps against the Office of Congressional Ethics.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — It was supposed to be a triumphant morning for Republicans on Capitol Hill — a moment to demonstrate the merits of unified party rule in the age of Donald J. Trump. By noon, party leaders had a message for their charges: It was not going smoothly.
articles.byline: By Eric Lipton and Matt Flegenheimer
